metadata.subject: The Most Powerful Scenes From Today's #BelieveSurvivors Protests

relationships.description: Ford accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault during high school
Ramirez accused Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct at Yale
Trump nominated Kavanaugh for Supreme Court

analysis.purpose: To document and showcase the nationwide #BelieveSurvivors protests supporting sexual assault survivors and opposing Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination
analysis.significance: Documents a significant moment in the #MeToo movement and the political controversy surrounding Kavanaugh's nomination, showing widespread public mobilization

notable_quotes: "I thought he might inadvertently kill me," Ford told the Post. "He was trying to attack me and remove my clothing."
"Women must be heard. Today I am wearing black in solidarity with Dr. Christine Blasey Ford." - Kerry Washington
red_flags: Death threats against Christine Blasey Ford

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion in this news article about public protests

illegal_activity.description: This is a news article reporting on public protests and allegations, not first-hand illegal activity

details: References to The New Yorker and Washington Post reporting
Extensive social media coverage through embedded tweets
Documentation of media personalities and celebrities participating

public_knowledge.context: This was major national news during the Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court confirmation hearings, widely covered by media outlets

analysis.summary: This news article documents the September 24, 2018 #BelieveSurvivors protests where people across the United States walked out of work and school to show support for Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez, who accused Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct, featuring participation from celebrities, politicians, and activists nationwide.
